thorwin.math

Interface Matrix

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Affine2D, Affine3D, Matrix2x2, Matrix3x3

    public interface Matrix
extends java.io.Serializable
    Real matrix.

    Matrices are created using one of the static construction methods:

    • columnPacked
    • diagonal
    • functional
    • identity
    • random
    • rowPacked
    • scalar
    • matrix
    • vandermonde

    All implementations of this interface returned by these methods are immutable, and therefore completely thread safe.

    Implementation Details

    The Matrix implementation have been designed to perform for both small and large matrices. The static constructor methods of this class will return matrix implementations that are designed for the specified dimensions and role.

    Small matrices will either store elements directly or in a packed array. Larger matrices will be automatically partitioned. Partitioning will benefit performance if the matrix can be divided into equal sized blocks. For optimal performance, choose dimensions that allow partitioning (avoid prime numbers).

    Operations will use parallel algorithms if they perform faster. In particular, operations on large matrices will executed on multiple threads.

    • Method Detail

      • columnPacked

        static Matrix columnPacked(int rowCount,
                           double... data)
        Constructs a matrix from a column packed array. The array contains data in the following order: M0,0, M1,0, M2,0, ... M0,1, M1,1, M2,1

        Note that the created matrix need not have its values stored column packed, it is just the format of the offered data.

        Parameters:
        rowCount - Number of rowsInBlock in a column
        data - The entry values
        Returns:
        matrix

      • rowPacked

        static Matrix rowPacked(int columnCount,
                        double... data)
        Constructs a matrix from a row packed array. The array contains data in the following order. M0,0, M0,1, M0,2, ... M1,0, M1,1, M1,2
        Parameters:
        columnCount - number of columns in a row
        data - element values values
        Returns:
        matrix

      • function

        static Matrix function(int rowCount,
                       int columnCount,
                       MatrixFunction matrixFunction)
        Constructs a matrix using a lambda expression. The provided lambda expression is expected to be functional:
        • It needs to operate on immutable input data (if any)
        • It should be without side effects

        Note that the functional matrix will evaluate each access to its elements. This may affect performance when elements are accessed repeatedly. All elements of the matrix may be evaluated and stored in memory using the evaluate() method.

        Parameters:
        rowCount - number of rows in the matrix
        columnCount - number of columns in the matrix
        matrixFunction - function that calculates the entries
        Returns:
        a functional matrix

      • valueOf

        static Matrix valueOf(java.lang.String matrix)
        Creates a matrix from a text string. Rows are delimited by semicolon (MATLAB) or newline characters. Columns are delimited by space characters.
        Parameters:
        matrix - matrix string
        Returns:
        constructed matrix
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the text can not be parsed as a matrix.

      • valueOf

        static Matrix valueOf(double[][] data)
        Constructs a matrix from the specified 2-dimensional ([row][column]) array. All getRowDimension should be defined (not null) and of equal length.
        Parameters:
        data - 2-dimensional array containing the elements
        Returns:
        constructed matrix

        static Matrix random(int rowCount,
                     int columnCount,
                     long seed)
        Creates a matrix with pseudo-random content.
        Parameters:
        rowCount - number of rows
        columnCount - number of columns
        seed - a random seed. Use constant for reproducible results, System.currentTimeMillis() for actual pseudo random value.
        Returns:
        constructed random matrix

      • vandermonde

        static Matrix vandermonde(int columns,
                          double... alphas)
        Creates a Vandermonde matrix.

        Example

        Matrix.vandermonde(3, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0) = 
          4.0000   2.0000   1.0000
  9.0000   3.0000   1.0000
  16.000   4.0000   1.0000
        Parameters:
        columns - number of getColumnDimension
        alphas - values of α, length will determine number of rows.
        Returns:
        a Vandermonde matrix
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on the Vandermonde Matrix

      • diagonal

        static Matrix diagonal(double... entries)
        Creates a diagonal matrix. A diagonal matrix is a square matrix where all entries are zero, except for the diagonal entries.
        Parameters:
        entries - diagonal elements
        Returns:
        a diagonal matrix

        Parameters:
        entries - diagonal elements
        Returns:
        a diagonal matrix

      • band

        static Matrix band(Matrix packed,
                   int rows,
                   int upperDiagonalCount)
        Creates a band matrix.

        A band matrix is a sparse matrix that only stores diagonal bands of the matrix. All values outside the band are zero. A band matrix stores fewer values. A band matrix saves memory and requires less processing power in various computations.

        The parent matrix should be in a specific format. Each row should contain a diagonal of the band.

        For example the following matrix: 

          1.1 1.2 1.3 0.0
  2.1 2.2 2.3 2.4
  0.0 3.2 3.3 3.4
  0.0 0.0 4.3 4.4
  0.0 0.0 0.0 5.4
        Is stored as: 
          0.0 0.0 1.3 2.4
  0.0 1.2 2.3 3.4
  1.1 2.2 3.3 4.4
  2.1 3.2 4.3 5.4
        This columnPacked form should be provided in this constructor.
        Parameters:
        packed - matrix, in packed form.
        rows - number of rows in the resulting matrix
        upperDiagonalCount - upper diagonals
        Returns:
        band matrix

      • getColumnDimension

        int getColumnDimension()
        The number of columns of this matrix.
        Returns:
        column dimension

      • getRowDimension

        int getRowDimension()
        Returns the number of rows in this matrix. The letter m is usually used to indicate a row dimension.
        Returns:
        number of rows

        double get(int row,
           int column)
        Returns the element value for the specified row and column index. The element indices are zero based.
        Parameters:

        column - column index of the element
        Returns:
        the element for the specified row and column indices
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the specified row or column indices are out of bounds

        Parameters:
        other - right hand side (B)
        Returns:
        solution if this matrix is square, least squares solution otherwise

      • identity

        static Matrix identity(int size)
        Creates the identity (or unit) matrix. The identity matrix is usually denoted by In, where n is its dimension. It is a square matrix, with ones on the main diagonal and zeros elsewhere.

        Im×A = A×In = A

        Parameters:
        size - The number of rows and columns
        Returns:
        the identity matrix
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on the Identity Matrix

      • isSquare

        default boolean isSquare()
        Determines if this is a square matrix. A matrix is square when its number of rows are equal to its number of columns.
        Returns:
        true if the matrix is square

      • lu

        default LU lu()
        Performs a Lower/Upper Decomposition.

        For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the LU decomposition is:

        • L, an m-by-n unit lower triangular matrix
        • U, an n-by-n upper triangular matrix
        • piv, a permutation vector of length m

        A(piv,:) = L×U.

        If m < n, then L is m-by-m and U is m-by-n.

        Returns:
        LU decomposition
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on LU decomposition

      • qr

        default QR qr()
        Performs a QR Decomposition

        For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the QR decomposition is:

        • Q, an m-by-n orthogonal matrix
        • R, an n-by-n upper triangular matrix

        A = Q×R

        Returns:
        QR Decomposition
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on QR Decomposition

      • scalar

        static Matrix scalar(int size,
                     double value)
        Creates a scalar matrix. A scalar matrix is a square matrix where all elements are zero, except for the diagonal elements. The diagonal elements all have the same value.
        Parameters:
        size - number of rows and columns
        value - value of the diagonal entries.
        Returns:
        a scalar matrix

        default java.util.Optional<? extends Vector> jacobi(Vector other,

                                                    double tolerance)
        Solves X for A×X = B using iterative method
        Parameters:

        iterations - maximum number of iterations to use
        tolerance - tolerance allowed for determining convergence
        Returns:
        Solution, if convergence is reached
        See Also:

        See Also:
        Wikipedia on Matrix Norm

      • norm2

        default double norm2()
        Returns the maximum singular value.
        Returns:
        two norm.
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on Matrix Norm

      • svd

        default SVD svd()
        Performs Singular Value Decomposition

        For an m-by-n matrix (A) the singular value decomposition is:

        • U, an m-by-n orthogonal matrix
        • S, an n-by-n diagonal matrix
        • V, an n-by-n orthogonal matrix

        A = U×S×V′

        The values of the singular values vector (sk = Sk,k) are descending.

        Returns:
        Singular value decomposition
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on Singular Value Decomposition

      • normFrobenius

        default double normFrobenius()
        Returns the square root of sum of squares of all elements.
        Returns:
        Frobenius norm
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on Matrix Norm

        Parameters:

        precision - precision used
        Returns:
        matrix as a text string

        Compares this matrix to another for equality. Note that this method has little mathematical applicability. It is mostly used for testing.
        Parameters:
        other - other matrix (not null)
        epsilon - maximum absolute difference between entries for them to be considered equal
        Returns:
        true, if the matrices are approximately equal

      • evaluate

        default Matrix evaluate()
        Evaluates the matrix. Evaluating the matrix ensures all values are calculated and present in the returned matrix, in such a way that re-querying single entries involves minimal computational overhead. This method is mostly applicable to matrices calculate their entries instead of having them stored.

        Calling this method on a matrix that already stores its entries in memory will not result in copying the matrix. In that case the matrix itself will be returned.

        Returns:
        evaluated matrix

      • getMatrix

        default Matrix getMatrix(int rowStart,
                         int rowEnd,
                         int columnStart,
                         int columnEnd)
        Returns a sub-matrix.
        Parameters:

        rowEnd - final row index
        columnStart - initial column index
        columnEnd - final column index
        Returns:
        the specified sub-matrix

        Returns a sub-matrix.

        columnStart - initial column index
        columnEnd - final column index
        Returns:
        sub-matrix

      • eig

        default Eigen eig()
        Performs an Eigendecomposition.

        If this matrix is symmetric, then the decomposition is:

        • D, the diagonal eigenvalue matrix
        • V, the orthogonal eigenvector matrix

        A = V×D×V′

        If this is not symmetric, then the decomposition is:

        • D, the block-diagonal eigenvalue matrix. The real eigenvalues in 1-b-1 blocks, and any complex eigenvalues in 2-by-2 blocks
        • V, the eigenvector matrix

        Note that matrix V may be badly conditioned (singular), so A = V×D×inverse(V) depends on V.norm1().

        Returns:
        Eigendecomposition.
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on Eigendecomposition of a Matrix

      • chol

        default Cholesky chol()
        Performs a Cholesky Decomposition. This matrix needs to be square, symmetric and positive definite.

        The Cholesky Decomposition is a lower triangular matrix L or R.

        A = L×L′ or A = R′×R

        Returns:
        Cholesky Decomposition
        See Also:
        Wikipedia on Cholesky Decomposition

      • negate

        default Matrix negate()
        Multiplies this matrix with -1.0
        Returns:
        matrix

      • multiply

        default Matrix multiply(double multiplicand)
        Multiplies this matrix with a real value (scale).
        Parameters:
        multiplicand - multiplicand
        Returns:
        resulting matrix

      • toArray

        default double[] toArray()
        Create a row-major packed array of the matrix.
        Returns:
        matrix in a a packed array
